moves.1. e4 e5 2. f4 exf4: As I think, the King's Gambit was a popular opening during the 19th century.
moves.3. Bc4: If I played, I prefer 3.Nf3 instead of 3.Bc4, because it avoids the annoying 3...Qh4+.
moves.3... Qh4+ 4. Kf1 b5: What was that? I think that Kieseritsky tried to activate the light squared bishop on a6-f1 diagonal by some moves later, where the white King was.
moves.5. Bxb5: As I think, 5.Nf3 followed by 6.Bb3 and 7.d3 (or d4 if possible) will give white a better control over the center. On the other hand, it was recapturing the pawn he offered in the second move.
moves.5... Nf6: Getting the control over the center is very important while it was attacking the pawn on e4.
moves.6. Nf3: Developing a horse, while attacking to the Queen, but 3.Nf3 is better according to me.
moves.6... Qh6 7. d3 Nh5: Black was trying to a breakthrough with 8...Ng3+. According to my opinion, it is better not to move the same piece in the opening moves, I like 7...c6 here.
moves.8. Nh4 Qg5: The queen was threatening to both the bishop and the horse. 9.Nf5 would stop that for a while.
moves.9. Nf5: It was the only way to protect both pieces.
moves.9... c6: Trying to create some space for the light squared bishop as well as a pawn moves towards the center.
moves.10. g4: An aggressive counterattack! Black could easily cut the bishop and there will be a huge blank squares around the white king. Because the king has been moved, it would be not difficult to launch an attack from the kingside.
moves.10... Nf6 11. Rg1: Anderssen was ignoring the piece and trying to attack the queen.
moves.13... Qg5 14. Qf3 Ng8: He had to move the horse, otherwise the Queen is trapped with 15.Bxf4. It had no better place than its home square.
moves.15. Bxf4 Qf6: Black was threatening 16.Qxb2 followed by capturing the trapped rook.
moves.16. Nc3: It stopped the threat but 16...b4 would force to move the same knight again.
moves.16... Bc5: It was taking the control over the a7-g1 diagonal, while attacking to the rook on g1.
moves.17. Nd5: He was giving up both the pawn and the rook, but, can you see how smoothly the white pieces come towards the black king?
moves.17... Qxb2 18. Bd6 Qxa1+: By this move, anyone can obviously see that black was becoming very greedy to obtain the rooks without offering anything.
moves.19. Ke2 Bxg1: 19...Qxg1 would not be as vulnerable as 19...Bxg1 as I see, because Bc5 was exerting pressure on Bd6.
moves.20. e5 Na6: I would not like that move, because white would do 20.Nc7+, if only he was badly needing the rook. And it was a blunder and a mate in 3 for white. Can you locate it?
moves.21. Nxg7+ Kd8: There was no other possible moves.
moves.22. Qf6+: All the thing needed to Anderssen was a CHECK as the black king's squares were attacked by the knights..
moves.22... Nxf6: Willingly or not, black had to capture it or to put 22.Ne7. Both are a mate in next move.
moves.23. Be7#: Though White was 21 points down, the game was ended in favor of White.
